I had a hyperfixation on this game and I gotta say that I enjoyed my time playing it. There is a unique feeling of first encountering a boss and wondering how it would even be possible to win until you optimize and wait for a while and end up one shotting it eventually. There is definitely an exponential difficulty curve which takes quite a lot of idler grinding to overcome but if you're into idle games with extreme end-games then I would check it out.

I've got a case of sunk cost fallacy playing this game. It takes me ages to progress and lots of manual oversight which makes me stare at the screen at progress bars for 30 minutes to make one item. I read a spoiler which lets you automate some actions, so I keep playing hoping to reach that point. Probably will need to retire from this game without ever beating it once (multiple endings by taking specific actions). I think it's a good game, but I don't have the patience to get through it. It's free, and I think there's people out there who love idlers and may love this game. So I'll recommend it for those fellow nutcases.

This one is a 6 out of 10, I would say. It's largely the same as the Kongregate version, and I do like it, but it has a lot of balance and information-sharing issues. Bluntly, you have to know EXACTLY how to Progress at certain points or you will sit there grinding forever and making no headway. It's frustrating to have to check the forums over and over to learn something that the game didn't communicate in the first place. The numbers are all right there, it's true, but that also means you have to know what they mean and how they actually impact gameplay, not to mention what you'll need to beat certain bosses. It's also annoying because the game implies a certain freedom of choice at points - branching paths to the same destination - but it's hard to feel like that matters when I really have to do things a certain way to get anywhere.

That DOES lighten up after you beat the Orc, for what it's worth, but after a point just opening the game feels more like work than play for me. YMMV.

Your choices shape everything. That‚Äôs the core of Text Idle RPG, a game where every decision nudges your story in new directions. With over 3,000 unique story actions and more added regularly, no two journeys feel exactly the same.
The gameplay balances simplicity and depth. You select actions with buttons, send monsters into automated dungeon battles, and enhance their skills and equipment. The Routine system rewards offline progress, so even when you‚Äôre away, your character grows stronger. As you advance, more automation and systems unlock, giving you tools to streamline your adventure or dive deeper into strategy.
The narrative hooks you immediately: starting from a small village, a father‚Äôs plea sets your quest in motion. You battle monsters, tackle quests, and form bonds with companions, all while your decisions influence the multiple possible endings.
Text Idle RPG is an idle game that never feels passive‚Äîyou‚Äôre shaping a story, leveling your monsters, and making meaningful choices every step of the way. 10/10 for a satisfying blend of narrative depth and idle mechanics.

Fist and most importantly this is NOT and idle game. resources have a max capacity, you can not set up auto loops of tasks and you need to micro manage almost every aspect of the game. leaving it siting untouched for 5 minutes means even though you are harvesting wheat you can only have a max of 10 so when you come back an hour later its all wasted time.

This is not an 'idle' game it's a game that asks you to do tedious micromanagement to progress. As other reviews say, you must babysit crafting that has multiple steps because of the very small resource caps and lack of any sort of automation or queuing of different actions. For certain kinds of progress leaving the game idle for long periods is fine, but then you will just end up with a backlog of tedium to catch up on in order to actually move forwards.

I think this game is fun. It's a neat time waster if you wanna see big numbers go up. That being said, I do not believe it's a game worth your time if you haven't already got into it. It's pretty annoying at times.

The problem is the capacity for all three items is 10 for the statues and the G statues take 3 wooden statues to make 1 and the wooden statues take 5 wood but my capacity for wood is at 28. Then I have to use the Goddess statues as part of an objective multiple times which leads me all the way back to square one. And this is just one example.

This completely takes the "idle" out of "idler".

This is not an idle game in any sense. Probably the least idle game to ever exist.
The amount of micromanaging required is honestly astounding. 

Every (and I mean every) single resource is capped. This means that if you (like an average idle game player) check in during a break or like every hour or so, you will find out that vast majority of that time was wasted doing absolutely nothing in-game, as it has already hit the cap early on.

This brings up another issue - over 70 hours in and there is no automation whatsoever. Everything still has to be clicked/set manually. Apparently there is something called "sloth" later on but if so, then over 50 hours in is already way too late.

Party. Holyyyy the party. Every single ally has to attack in order, and it doesnt reset between battles. Adding more creatures is geniuenly hurting the experience - In exchange for the passives, you essentialy add timewasting to the dungeons, you cannot decide who, when, what or anything, its just from top to bottom. Majority of the 'combat' is just waiting for the mobs in front to die so the actual heavy hitters live longer. Also enemies hit so hard there is no point in using the any ally's ability - you just have to set them to the fastest hitting attack, otherwise they just die in one hit doing nothing.

Menus. There is a lot on menus. A LOT. 

This is not an idle game. The only idle part is certain actions taking real life time, other than that its a point-and-click adventure. With RNG attached.

For an idle, it sure does quite make sure you are constantly paying attention to it. Not only is production of materials not automatic, they also have a limit on how much you could produce and keep. It is tedious!

I've played a lot of Idle/Grinder games over the years, but this one... it beats them all in a sense of there being too many things to have to swap constantly if you want to maximize the gains, and that's not necessarily a *bad* thing, but it certainly defeats the purpose of having something to run in the background.
I wish I could say I found this to be entertaining, as I love the simplicity of the UI and all, but I really just can't.
I don't generally spend less than 20 hours on a given game before reviewing, but I couldn't bring myself to justify doing so with this one.
At the same time this game takes so much interaction and makes no progress, such a weird mix.

Neat premise, but feels more like eve in what it wants you to do in fights. 

Hit a hard wall that the only option is painful grinding of time in likely weeks of time, and in an incremental, thats a no sell. 

Thankfully free, but do not get. Do not bother with your time. There are better ones out there.

Interesting game with potential, but it has wayyyy to much screen time where you just wait for stuff to be collected (you cant idle because its only 10 max items, then you have to collect 10 other items to make them again etc. etc.) the connection should be made idle at some point so you dont spend 100 hours just to finish 1 quest. if more stuff would be idle and the overview / menu would be a bit cleaner and easier you could have alot of fun with this as a second screen game or whatever. to be clear, its fine to click some stuff manually and not have everything idle but its way to much here.
I regret spending 3.9h in this game...
Worst UI i ever seen.
not idler

This is not an idle game in any sense. Probably the least idle game to ever exist.
The amount of micromanaging required is honestly astounding. 

Every (and I mean every) single resource is capped. This means that if you (like an average idle game player) check in during a break or like every hour or so, you will find out that vast majority of that time was wasted doing absolutely nothing in-game, as it has already hit the cap early on.

This brings up another issue - over 70 hours in and there is no automation whatsoever. Everything still has to be clicked/set manually. Apparently there is something called "sloth" later on but if so, then over 50 hours in is already way too late.

Party. Holyyyy the party. Every single ally has to attack in order, and it doesnt reset between battles. Adding more creatures is geniuenly hurting the experience - In exchange for the passives, you essentialy add timewasting to the dungeons, you cannot decide who, when, what or anything, its just from top to bottom. Majority of the 'combat' is just waiting for the mobs in front to die so the actual heavy hitters live longer. Also enemies hit so hard there is no point in using the any ally's ability - you just have to set them to the fastest hitting attack, otherwise they just die in one hit doing nothing.

Menus. There is a lot on menus. A LOT. 

This is not an idle game. The only idle part is certain actions taking real life time, other than that its a point-and-click adventure. With RNG attached.

For an idle, it sure does quite make sure you are constantly paying attention to it. Not only is production of materials not automatic, they also have a limit on how much you could produce and keep. It is tedious!

I've played a lot of Idle/Grinder games over the years, but this one... it beats them all in a sense of there being too many things to have to swap constantly if you want to maximize the gains, and that's not necessarily a *bad* thing, but it certainly defeats the purpose of having something to run in the background.
I wish I could say I found this to be entertaining, as I love the simplicity of the UI and all, but I really just can't.
I don't generally spend less than 20 hours on a given game before reviewing, but I couldn't bring myself to justify doing so with this one.
At the same time this game takes so much interaction and makes no progress, such a weird mix.

Neat premise, but feels more like eve in what it wants you to do in fights. 

Hit a hard wall that the only option is painful grinding of time in likely weeks of time, and in an incremental, thats a no sell. 

Thankfully free, but do not get. Do not bother with your time. There are better ones out there.

This is not an 'idle' game it's a game that asks you to do tedious micromanagement to progress. As other reviews say, you must babysit crafting that has multiple steps because of the very small resource caps and lack of any sort of automation or queuing of different actions. For certain kinds of progress leaving the game idle for long periods is fine, but then you will just end up with a backlog of tedium to catch up on in order to actually move forwards.

Wish there was a maybe recommend for this one. 

Fist and most importantly this is NOT and idle game. resources have a max capacity, you can not set up auto loops of tasks and you need to micro manage almost every aspect of the game. leaving it siting untouched for 5 minutes means even though you are harvesting wheat you can only have a max of 10 so when you come back an hour later its all wasted time.

This is more of a RPG that can be slow and tedious at times. but there are times it can be fun as well. if you  have the time to atend to the game its fine. if you want an idle game this is not for you.

For a game designed in 2021, it wouldn't pass for a DOS based single developer game.  The interface layout just doesn't make any sense, its as if 'alignment' doesnt exist.  Everything is everywhere. From the very beginning, it is very click intensive and not 'idle' at all.
